title: Thursday, 16th February, 2017

11:17 am

BE11:17am

Balance sheet "clearly not strong enough"

BE11:18am

If anyone can find a reason to own Cobham right now, even as a recovery play, I'm all ears.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Here's UBS to talk us through the moving parts.

BE11:18am

Cobham announced that 2016 underlying trading profit is expected at £225m (vs. UBSe £244m, previous guidance £245m). Net debt/EBITDA at the end of 2016 is expected to be 3x (vs. covenant 3.5x), following 80% cash conversion. 2017 guidance came in below expectations – management believes that delivering a similar performance to that of 2016 may be challenging. (UBSe £263m 2017 EBIT, cons £269m). Assuming performance in line with 2016 would imply a cut to consensus expectations of ~15%. We believe this poses risks to the balance sheet – management is expected to offer more guidance at the FY results on 2 March.

BE11:18am

Cobham also announced a charge of £150m related to Cobham covering the costs to complete the development schedule on the air-to-air refuelling unit. The charge reflects both potential historical liabilities related to the program as well as future work on the program.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

In addition, management will recognize a £574m goodwill and other intangible impairment, taken mostly against the Aeroflex acquisition and the Integrated Electronic Solutions unit. In our opinion, this illustrates overpayment on the Aeroflex acquisition, and it helps the company to clear the decks for the future.

BE11:19am

Our 145p PT is driven by our DCF model and is based on a WACC of 9% and a long-term growth rate of 2%.

Cobham PLC (COB:LSE): Last: 111.00, down 24.4 (-18.02%), High: 120.00, Low: 102.50, Volume: 16.87m
11:19 am
PM11:19am

Blimey, ive just scrolled down to the "Early view of 2017" int he statement

BE11:20am

Drastic, isn't it.

PM11:20am

Would sharing taht

11:19 am
PM11:20am

Early view of 2017

The Board has not yet finished its review of the 2017 budget.

Whilst market uncertainties undoubtedly exist, the ability of the Group to forecast performance is also not as strong as it should be and these factors lead to the early view for 2017 at this stage of the year having a wide range of potential outcomes.

PM11:20am

The Group has many operational issues which require attention in addition to reversing the current negative performance trajectory. Some actions to address these have already commenced but are in an early stage. Such actions may also have associated costs. Given these and the issues highlighted above the Board considers that delivery of a similar performance to that of 2016 in 2017 may be challenging.

PM11:20am

The balance sheet is clearly not strong enough to properly support the operations of the Group, given the important role it plays in many customer programmes. A strong balance sheet will be an important part of delivering medium term growth. The Board is not sufficiently advanced in the review of the forecast financial position of the Group to be able to give any balance sheet guidance today. This will be provided in the preliminary results announcement on 2 March 2017.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

So they need a rights issue but can't give any kind of outlook required for finding a value for the shares they'll be issuing.

PM11:21am

'We need an emergency refinancing, but we don't even have our ducks in a row for that'

BE11:21am

Yep. That's pretty bleak.

11:21 am
PM11:21am

Just shocking

BE11:21am

Here's Jefferies, which I think is house.

BE11:21am

Conclusion: Update sounds pretty grim. Major item is £150m charge on KC-46, “which
fully bounds historic liabilities and appropriately funds the remaining work, after taking into
account historic performance". We believe the fundamental issue to be how much of the
£150m is a write-down of existing work-in-progress – at end FY16 we estimate that at around
£100-120m. If so, the forward cash implication is quite modest. The scale of the latter will
also heavily influence the extent to which the balance sheet needs strengthening. The need
for the latter is clearly signalled, in our view.

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Details: The material write-downs of goodwill are not germane to cash flow, in our view.
FY16 underlying trading profit now guided at £225m versus last update of £245m. End FY16
net debt still stated at £1,030m. That the latter hasn’t changed is some modest comfort.

BE11:22am

That's Sandy Morris. Between this and Rolls, he's had a difficult time from the house clients.

PM11:22am

Market insiders say that, despite a general trend away from lunchtime drinking elsewhere in the City, it is still popular in the insurance world. “It still goes on more than you might expect. There is still a short hours and long lunch culture in some places and there are stories of brokers sitting in pubs handing out contracts like Jabba the Hutt,” said one person close to the insurance market.

11:37 am
PM11:37am

But sorry - go on

BE11:37am

Leadenhall Market lost its last functioning butcher a week or so, I think. It's all pubs and bars now.

BE11:37am

Yes, back to Lancashire. Beats on reserve release, underlying mediocre and outlook still cautious.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Barclays incoming.

BE11:38am

Lancashire posted a strong beat on earnings with Q4 profit before tax of $50.9m some 64% ahead of consensus of $31m, 36% ahead of our estimate of $37m and 1.4% growth YoY. The gross premiums of $95m were 4% ahead of consensus and broadly in line with our estimate. But the significant earnings beat was driven by higher than expected net premiums earned of $128m over Q4 compared to our estimate of $93m and prior year favourable development of $23.9m, primarily coming from Cathedral book ($20m reserve release) driven by lack of reported claims.

Gross premiums of $95m over the quarter declined 2% compared to 4Q15 despite rates declining upto 10%. Comparing the gross premiums would indicate significant growth in energy book (57%) and decline in marine, aviation and Lloyd’s. However, most of the changes in gross premiums were driven by the timing impact of multi-year deals and the cancellation and replacement of certain contracts. Overall, Lancashire is defending its core book with disciplined underwriting but weak pricing outlook continues to drive negative expectations on growth in top line.

BE11:38am

The Q4 combined ratio at 79% was 2.6ppts better than consensus. The combined ratio saw a 17ppts favourable prior year development with reserve releases of $23.9m over Q4, largely driven by $20m releases from Lloyd’s business (Cathedral). Lancashire took a reserve charge of $18m (Barclays estimate - $15m) for 2009 accident year in relation to Noreco oil company potential claims. This additional reserve charge was more than offset by the IBNR releases from 2014 and 2015 accident years due to low reported claims. Earlier this year a Danish court passed a judgement that some 24 insurers should pay $470m for damage caused to Noreco’s Siri oil platform in 2009. The insurers have appealed against this decision. Lancashire’s $18m provision could be released in future if the appeal is successful. Overall, there were no major losses over the quarter.

In 2016 with $0.1 dividend per share declared in Q4 the company has paid $0.9 dividend per share, returning 113.3% of earnings. Market conditions remain challenging for Lancashire and the company expects to see challenging environment in 2017. Overall, we remain cautious on top line growth expectations for Lancashire with 2017 expected to have a similar story seen in 2016 – disciplined underwriting with focus on margins and defending core book combined with high dividend expectations from returning earnings as well as capital to shareholders due to limited growth opportunities.

The total capital available was $1.5bn, comprising shareholders’ equity of $1.2bn and $0.3bn of debt. Tangible capital at FY16 was $1.4bn, which remained around company’s threshold capital range of $1.3bn to $1.4bn. We expect Lancashire to continue to manage the ROE by managing capital (returning excess not required for growth) in the absence of profitable growth opportunities.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

And Morgan Stanley, which is shop.

BE11:39am

The 4Q combined ratio is 79.0% vs consensus of 81.6%. On an accident year
basis, the loss ratio was 49.6% with ~19% ($24m) of reserve releases (vs MSe AY
loss ratio 37.2%). We have previously highlighted that reserve releases can be
volatile given the short tail nature of Lancashire's book, and we are not
concerned regarding reserving strength of Lancashire vs peers. However, we still
expect some market focus on reserve releases. We had expected net reserve
strengthening in 4Q (MSe: 6.5% or $9m) with a large portion owing to a marketwide energy claim, however there were releases across more recent accident
years, resulting in a net positive reserve release.
We believe that other drivers of the PBT beat are due to a higher net investment
result ($13.3m vs MSe $6.8m) with higher released gains and gains on the
derivatives portfolio, lower expenses owing to a stronger USD vs GBP, and some
timing differences, for example profit commissions in Cathedral which were
received in 4Q that were not in our estimates.

BE11:39am

Further reduction in risk exposure levels with increased reinsurance purchasing.
We note that Lancashire's estimated net loss to peak zone nat cat exposures are
now 7% of shareholders' equity on average, vs 9% one year ago.
Higher capital buffer suggests more positive outlook for 2017. We believe that
management are holding back capital to deploy over the course of 2017, and
think that Lancashire is well positioned should capital begin to leave the industry
(for example, we have seen signs of reserve weakness in the industry over the
course of 4Q16)

11:40 am

11:43 am
PM11:43am

Let me share his stuff on Yellen

PM11:44am

In her eagerly awaited testimony before Congress, Janet Yellen warned against the perils of the Fed delaying raising interest rates, stating “As I noted on previous occasions, waiting too long to remove accommodation would be unwise.” You what? Is this some sort of joke? Yellen has presided over a Fed that has dithered, dallied and dodged raising rates for the last few years, wheeling out feeble, data-dependent excuse after feeble excuse. We all know that the only data the Fed is really focused on is the daily S&P print.

PM11:44am

This tardiness to normalise rates is exactly what we saw in the noughties – with catastrophic results. Yes, the Greenspan Fed did raise rates from 1% in mid-2004 to 51⁄4% by 2006, but the pace was far too slow and the timing far too late. Their extreme caution so as not to upset financial markets was most evident in the fact that in 17 rate hikes they never raised rates by more than 1⁄4%. My former boss at the Bank of England, Paul Mortimer-Lee (now Chief Economist at BNP Paribas) criticised this slow pace of tightening at the time. I heard him on the radio likening it to boiling a frog. If you put a frog in cold water and heat it, the frog won’t jump out whereas if you drop the frog in hot water it reacts immediately - I’m not sure how he knew this but I avoided supper at his place thereafter!

11:44 am
PM11:44am

John Taylor (of the Taylor rule) was also withering in his criticism of Greenspan’s slow pace to normalise interest rates. His rule suggested that rates should have been hiked aggressively from 2002 onwards and he excoriated Greenspan for his “disingenuous” excuse that the bubble was caused not by the Fed’s easy money, but by surplus Chinese savings – link. I am compiling a list of vituperative phases for the day when the Yellen credit bubble finally bursts and sinks the economy. Just like the Greenspan Fed, the die has been cast and it is simply too late for the Yellen Fed to avoid a disaster.

PM11:44am

PM11:46am

One extra par

11:45 am
PM11:46am

￼
Traditionally the most closely watched commodity as an indicator for the strength of the global economy is the price of copper. The front cover chart clearly shows this has broken out of its five-year downtrend, and our own technical analyst, Stephanie Aymes, believes that the price move is gaining further traction – link. When at Kleinwort’s, one thing we used to look at was the breadth of commodity price rises (or declines) as an indication of the strength (or weakness) of the economic cycle. That prevents surges in one or two individual commodity prices dominating the commodity baskets – usually copper, which has a much higher weighting in most baskets due to its heavy industrial usage.

PM11:54am

A trader or traders in the options market made an estimated profit of 400 per cent betting on a big move in Fortress Investment Group shares on Tuesday, just hours before the private equity firm announced a $3.3bn takeover offer from SoftBank.

The size of the bets raised eyebrows and led several options market experts to suspect that someone was trading on information that had leaked about the deal, which surprised the private equity industry when it was announced later in the day.

“There was a biggish trade and then there was a colossal trade,” said Ophir Gottlieb, chief executive of Capital Market Laboratories. “This is a pretty glaring example of likely impropriety.”
